1.title: Tekien
1.summary: Mobile application listing CY Tech's student associations and their events.

paragraphs.title: Goal
paragraphs.text:
The goal of this project was to port an existing website to mobile. The website's purpose was to centralize information about CY Tech associations and their events.

Having all this information accessible on a phone allows students to easily stay informed about the different associations and enjoy a more fulfilling campus life.

paragraphs.title: Implementation
paragraphs.text:
To carry out this project, we took the logic of the existing website, originally developed with Vue.js. For the mobile version, we decided to use React and Ionic to offer a different implementation and a fresh experience.

We retrieve association and event data through an API developed by the team maintaining the website.

paragraphs.title: New features
paragraphs.text:
This mobile version allowed us to introduce new features.

We implemented a favorites system so users can follow their favorite associations instead of browsing the entire list each time.

It is now possible to customize the app's theme and switch between French and English.

Finally, one of the most important additions is notifications. Users can now “subscribe” to events and receive reminders when those events are about to start.

These additions make the app more useful for a wide range of students and help promote student associations.

2.title: 3D Engine
2.summary: A basic 3D engine to visualize a model from different perspectives.

paragraphs.title: Project goal
paragraphs.text:
The goal of this project was to create a 3D engine using OpenGL to understand how it works.

To do this, I implemented a shader system using .frag and .vert files. It is possible to move and rotate the 3D model to better observe the engine's behavior.

paragraphs.title: Light and shadow
paragraphs.text:
The light's position and color can be adjusted to better observe shadows.

It also supports two shading models: Phong and Gouraud. These two implementations help visualize different ways of handling shading.

3.title: CY Books
3.summary: A project aimed at developing a library management application.

paragraphs.title: Features
paragraphs.text:
This project includes several features:

  • Book management
  • User management
  • Borrowing management

Everything is handled in a database using SQLite.

paragraphs.title: Book management
paragraphs.text: Books and their details are retrieved from the Gallica API of the French National Library (BnF). This allows us to filter books by title, author, or publisher.

paragraphs.title: User management
paragraphs.text:
Users are stored in an SQLite database to easily create, edit, and delete them.

Each user has a profile page displaying their information and the books they have borrowed.

paragraphs.title: Borrowing management
paragraphs.text:
Just like users, borrowings are stored in an SQLite database. Each borrowing has a return deadline that helps track overdue books — this updates automatically.

Borrowings can also be filtered by their status: overdue, ongoing, or completed.

4.title: Space Shooter
4.summary: A small space shooter game made with the Godot engine.

paragraphs.title: Development
paragraphs.text:
The game was created using the Godot engine and its scripting language, GDScript. I focused on a small project with a simple game loop to get familiar with Godot.

The main features implemented are player movement, a shooting system, enemy spawning, and a final boss.

paragraphs.title: Gameplay
paragraphs.text:
The goal is simple: defeat enough enemies to unlock and defeat the boss.

There are three types of enemies with different behaviors:

  • The first moves straight downward.
  • The second is similar but faster and moves in an oscillating pattern.
  • The third tries to align with the player to shoot at them.

paragraphs.title: Boss behavior
paragraphs.text: The boss is built as a finite state machine. Each state corresponds to a behavior or attack pattern and changes every few seconds. There's no fixed order, so the player must adapt quickly to each new phase.

5.title: Battleship
5.summary: A command-line Battleship game developed in C.

paragraphs.title: The game
paragraphs.text: This C game follows the classic Battleship rules. Players must place their ships and sink the opponent's fleet. The game is played solo against the computer.

paragraphs.title: The computer
paragraphs.text: The computer has a very simple AI: it fires randomly until it hits one of the player's ships. However, if it repeatedly selects already-hit cells, it switches to scanning all cells sequentially until it finds an untouched one.

paragraphs.title: Comments
paragraphs.text: The code is fully documented using Doxygen conventions, allowing for quick generation of a clear and structured documentation.
